author: Tom Pullar-strecker
title: Tourism industry calls for border tax to be scrapped or delayed
text:
Tourism industry calls for border tax to be scrapped or delayed TOM PULLAR-STRECKER Last updated 12:14, July 28 2015 
Coalition Against Travel Tax spokesman Chris Roberts says border checks are a "public good" that should be funded by taxpayers, not travellers. 
The tourism industry will take a $104 million annual hit if the Government presses ahead with a "border clearance levy" on international travellers, airlines and hotels say. 
Airlines, airports, the cruise industry and accommodation providers have united in their opposition to the introduction of the $22 charge which was proposed in the May budget, suggesting it could even result in airlines axing flights to some destinations. 
Primary Industries Minister Nathan Guy has suggested travellers could be charged $16 for arriving in New Zealand and $6 on departure, from January. 
READ MORE: International airfares will rise new departure tax 
Guy said the levy would bring New Zealand into line with other countries by ensuring that international travellers rather than taxpayers met the cost of Customs and biosecurity checks. 
But the Coalition Against Travel Tax, which has been established to fight the proposal, said a study commissioned by the Government estimated the levy would reduce the number of international visitors by 1.4 per cent and their spending by 0.9 per cent. 
"This equates to a loss of 44,000 visitors a year and spending of $104m," the lobby group said, adding that analysis by international airlines and cruise companies suggested the impact could be greater than the study forecast. 
The coalition said New Zealand travellers would pay almost half the fees and urged the Government to at least delay the levy until 2017 while more analysis was done on its likely impact. 
Tourism Industry Association chief executive Chris Roberts, who is the spokesman for the coalition, accused the Government of downplaying the impact of the levy which he said would be a "handbrake on the growing visitor economy". 
Roberts said it was long-standing in New Zealand that border services were a "public good" and should therefore be funded through general taxation. Ad Feedback 
"A small bad tax is still a bad tax. It is an unwelcome signal being sent by the Government that it is willing to impose risks on efforts to grow the value of the visitor economy, contrary to the goals of its own Business Growth Agenda," he said. 
Any move that discouraged travel could "impact on the economics of airline services and adversely impact on air connectivity", the coalition said in a statement. 
If the levy was introduced, it should not be subject to GST, and a "traveller reference group" should be set up to monitor how the raised funds were spent, it said. 
Roberts said the levy had been proposed in haste and without any consultation. 
Regulatory Reform Minister Steven Joyce said in a separate statement on Tuesday that the Government intended to take a more collaborative approach to government regulation. 
Responding to a Productivity Commission report, he said the Government wanted "a more productive and collaborative approach between regulators and their stakeholders". 
"We want to use more open book exercises and more exposure drafts, to in effect crowd-source improvements to regulations," he said. - Stuff
